rows: Brain damage, visual impairment, intellectual disability
Variable; syphilis can cause bone/tooth abnormalities, hearing loss
Deafness, heart defects, cataracts, intellectual disability (especially dangerous in first trimester)
Neonatal herpes can cause encephalitis; risk is highest during vaginal delivery with active lesions
questions.correct_value: Most common congenital viral infection; hearing loss, intellectual disability
options: Deafness, heart defects, cataracts, intellectual disability (especially dangerous in first trimester)
Most common congenital viral infection; hearing loss, intellectual disability
Brain damage, visual impairment, intellectual disability
Neonatal herpes can cause encephalitis; risk is highest during vaginal delivery with active lesions
questions.explanation: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is notable for being the MOST COMMON congenital viral infection, a frequently tested fact on the EPPP. Its key prenatal effects include hearing loss and intellectual disability. This is commonly confused with Rubella, which also causes deafness and intellectual disability but is additionally associated with heart defects and cataracts and is especially dangerous in the first trimester.

rows: Declines; reduced capacity and processing speed
Declines, especially free recall; recognition memory better preserved
questions.correct_value: Mixed; time-based declines, event-based relatively stable
options: Declines, especially free recall; recognition memory better preserved
Mixed; time-based declines, event-based relatively stable
Relatively stable; may even increase
Well-preserved
questions.explanation: Prospective memory shows a mixed pattern with aging: time-based prospective memory (remembering to do something at a specific time) declines, while event-based prospective memory (remembering to do something when triggered by an external cue) remains relatively stable. This distinction is important because it highlights how the availability of external cues can support memory performance in older adults.

rows: Stroke cheek or corner of mouth
Head turns toward stimulus, mouth opens
Sudden loud noise or loss of support
Arms extend, then draw inward; crying
Toes fan out, big toe extends
Held upright with feet touching surface
questions.correct_value: 8–12 months
options: 5–6 months
3–4 months
8–12 months
2–3 months
questions.explanation: The Babinski reflex (toes fan out and big toe extends when the sole of the foot is stroked) disappears by 8–12 months, making it the longest-lasting neonatal reflex listed. This is commonly tested because it persists significantly longer than other reflexes such as Moro (5–6 months) or palmar grasp (3–4 months), and its persistence beyond 12 months can indicate neurological abnormality.

rows: Has explored alternatives and made firm commitments. Associated with the best psychological outcomes: high self-esteem, mature reasoning, and strong relationships.
Actively exploring identity alternatives but has not yet committed. Often characterized by anxiety and questioning, but this is a healthy and necessary process.

No exploration and no commitment. May appear apathetic or aimless. Associated with the poorest outcomes when it persists. In early adolescence, this is normative; in late adolescence/adulthood, it is concerning.
questions.correct_value: Has made commitments without exploration -- typically adopting parents' or authority figures' values without question. Appears stable but may be rigid and defensive when beliefs are challenged.
options: Actively exploring identity alternatives but has not yet committed. Often characterized by anxiety and questioning, but this is a healthy and necessary process.
Has made commitments without exploration -- typically adopting parents' or authority figures' values without question. Appears stable but may be rigid and defensive when beliefs are challenged.

No exploration and no commitment. May appear apathetic or aimless. Associated with the poorest outcomes when it persists. In early adolescence, this is normative; in late adolescence/adulthood, it is concerning.
Has explored alternatives and made firm commitments. Associated with the best psychological outcomes: high self-esteem, mature reasoning, and strong relationships.
questions.explanation: Foreclosure is defined by the presence of commitment but the absence of crisis (exploration). The individual has adopted values — typically from parents or authority figures — without personally exploring alternatives. This distinguishes it from Identity Achievement (which involves both exploration and commitment), Moratorium (exploration without commitment), and Identity Diffusion (neither exploration nor commitment).

questions.correct_value: Fidelity
options: Purpose
Competence
Fidelity
Will
questions.explanation: In Erikson's psychosocial framework, the successful resolution of the Identity vs. Role Confusion crisis during adolescence yields the virtue of Fidelity — the ability to sustain loyalties and commitments to others despite inevitable contradictions in one's value system. This is commonly confused with virtues from adjacent stages such as Competence (Stage 4) or Purpose (Stage 3).

rows: Secure: Comfortable with intimacy and autonomy
Dismissing: Self-reliant; deactivates attachment; dismisses importance of relationships
Fearful-avoidant: Desires closeness but fears rejection; both activates and deactivates attachment
questions.correct_value: Preoccupied: Seeks excessive closeness; hypervigilant to rejection; hyperactivates attachment system
options: Fearful-avoidant: Desires closeness but fears rejection; both activates and deactivates attachment
Preoccupied: Seeks excessive closeness; hypervigilant to rejection; hyperactivates attachment system
Dismissing: Self-reliant; deactivates attachment; dismisses importance of relationships
Secure: Comfortable with intimacy and autonomy
questions.explanation: In Bartholomew and Horowitz's (1991) dimensional model, the Preoccupied style results from a negative model of self combined with a positive model of others. This leads to seeking excessive closeness and hyperactivating the attachment system due to feelings of unworthiness paired with valuing others. This is commonly confused with the Fearful-avoidant style, which also involves a negative self-model but pairs it with a negative model of others, resulting in a conflicted pattern of both activating and deactivating attachment.

rows: Sets clear standards but is warm and responsive; encourages independence; explains rules; open communication
Best outcomes: high self-esteem, social competence, academic achievement, self-regulation
Strict rules with little warmth; obedience valued over dialogue; punitive discipline; "because I said so"
Obedient but lower self-esteem, social skills, and happiness; more anxiety and aggression
Warm and accepting but few demands or controls; avoids confrontation; lenient rules
Disengaged; provides basic needs but little guidance, warmth, or attention
Worst outcomes: attachment problems, poor self-regulation, academic failure, delinquency
questions.correct_value: Poor self-regulation, impulsivity, low academic achievement; may be socially skilled
options: Obedient but lower self-esteem, social skills, and happiness; more anxiety and aggression
Poor self-regulation, impulsivity, low academic achievement; may be socially skilled
Worst outcomes: attachment problems, poor self-regulation, academic failure, delinquency
Best outcomes: high self-esteem, social competence, academic achievement, self-regulation
questions.explanation: Permissive (Indulgent) parents are high in responsiveness/warmth but low in demandingness, meaning children lack structure and discipline. This leads to poor self-regulation, impulsivity, and low academic achievement, but because the parent is warm and accepting, these children may still develop some social skills. This distinguishes permissive outcomes from uninvolved parenting, which produces the worst outcomes across all domains due to lack of both warmth and structure.

rows: High self-esteem, social competence, academic achievement, self-regulation
Poor self-regulation, impulsivity, entitled behavior, academic difficulties
Worst outcomes across domains; attachment difficulties, behavioral problems
questions.correct_value: Obedient but less happy, more anxious, lower self-esteem, potential aggression
options: Poor self-regulation, impulsivity, entitled behavior, academic difficulties
Obedient but less happy, more anxious, lower self-esteem, potential aggression
High self-esteem, social competence, academic achievement, self-regulation
Worst outcomes across domains; attachment difficulties, behavioral problems
questions.explanation: The Authoritarian parenting style is characterized by high demandingness but low responsiveness. Children tend to be obedient due to strict rules and expectations, but the lack of warmth and responsiveness leads to lower happiness, increased anxiety, lower self-esteem, and potential aggression. This distinguishes it from the Authoritative style (which produces the best outcomes due to both high demandingness and high responsiveness) and the Permissive style (where low demandingness leads to poor self-regulation and impulsivity rather than obedience).

rows: Uses caregiver as secure base for exploration; may be distressed by separation; greets caregiver positively on reunion and is quickly soothed
Rejecting, emotionally unavailable, or uncomfortable with close physical contact
Highly distressed by separation; on reunion, shows ambivalent behavior -- seeks contact but also resists comfort (pushing away, angry crying). Difficult to soothe
Inconsistently responsive -- sometimes available, sometimes not. Unpredictable
No coherent attachment strategy; shows contradictory behaviors (approaching while looking away, freezing, stereotypies). The caregiver is simultaneously the source of comfort and the source of fear
Frightening or frightened behavior; often associated with maltreatment, unresolved trauma, or parental psychopathology
questions.correct_value: Shows little distress at separation; ignores or avoids caregiver on reunion; appears indifferent. Physiological measures reveal elevated stress despite apparent calm
options: No coherent attachment strategy; shows contradictory behaviors (approaching while looking away, freezing, stereotypies). The caregiver is simultaneously the source of comfort and the source of fear
Highly distressed by separation; on reunion, shows ambivalent behavior -- seeks contact but also resists comfort (pushing away, angry crying). Difficult to soothe
Shows little distress at separation; ignores or avoids caregiver on reunion; appears indifferent. Physiological measures reveal elevated stress despite apparent calm
Uses caregiver as secure base for exploration; may be distressed by separation; greets caregiver positively on reunion and is quickly soothed
questions.explanation: Insecure-Avoidant (Type A) infants characteristically appear indifferent to separation and avoid the caregiver upon reunion, seeming emotionally unaffected. However, a key EPPP-testable detail is that physiological measures (e.g., cortisol levels) reveal elevated stress despite this outward calm, indicating the infant is suppressing attachment behaviors rather than truly being unaffected. This distinguishes Type A from Type C (ambivalent), where distress is overtly and intensely expressed.

rows: No stage theory; development is continuous
questions.correct_value: Self-regulatory (functional, becomes inner speech)
options: Egocentric (immature, declines with age)
Reflects cognitive level
Self-regulatory (functional, becomes inner speech)
Drives cognitive development
questions.explanation: Vygotsky viewed private speech as self-regulatory and functional, serving as a cognitive tool that gradually becomes internalized as inner speech. This contrasts with Piaget, who considered private speech to be egocentric and a sign of cognitive immaturity that declines with age. This distinction is a high-yield EPPP topic because it highlights the fundamental theoretical difference between the two theorists regarding the role of language in cognitive development.

questions.section: Stages of the Family Life Cycle
rows: Accepting emotional and financial responsibility for self
Differentiation of self from family of origin; developing intimate peer relationships; establishing career identity
Forming a marital/partnership system; realigning relationships with extended families and friends to include the partner
Accepting new members into the system
Adjusting the couple system to make space for children; taking on parenting roles; realigning relationships with extended family to include grandparenting roles
Shifting parent-child relationships to permit the adolescent's growing autonomy; refocusing on midlife marital and career issues; beginning to attend to aging parents
Accepting multiple exits from and entries into the family

Renegotiating the couple system as a dyad; developing adult-to-adult relationships with grown children; realigning relationships to include in-laws and grandchildren; dealing with aging and death of grandparents

Maintaining functioning and interests in the face of physiological decline; supporting the middle generation; making room for the wisdom and experience of the elderly; dealing with loss of spouse, siblings, and peers; preparation for death and life review
questions.correct_value: Increasing flexibility of family boundaries
options: Accepting new members into the system
Accepting multiple exits from and entries into the family
Increasing flexibility of family boundaries
Accepting shifting generational roles
questions.explanation: The 'Families with adolescents' stage is characterized by the key emotional process of 'Increasing flexibility of family boundaries,' which reflects the need for the family system to become more permeable to allow the adolescent greater autonomy. This is distinct from adjacent stages: 'Accepting new members' applies to families with young children, and 'Accepting multiple exits and entries' applies to the launching stage.

rows: No exploration, no commitments. May appear apathetic or directionless.
Actively exploring options but has not yet committed. May appear anxious or in crisis.
Has explored alternatives and made firm commitments. Most psychologically healthy status.
questions.correct_value: Commitment without exploration. Adopts identity from authority figures (parents, religion) without questioning.
options: No exploration, no commitments. May appear apathetic or directionless.
Commitment without exploration. Adopts identity from authority figures (parents, religion) without questioning.
Actively exploring options but has not yet committed. May appear anxious or in crisis.
Has explored alternatives and made firm commitments. Most psychologically healthy status.
questions.explanation: Identity Foreclosure is characterized by high commitment but low exploration. The individual adopts values, beliefs, and goals from authority figures (e.g., parents, religion) without personally questioning or exploring alternatives. This distinguishes it from Identity Diffusion (no commitment or exploration), Moratorium (active exploration without commitment), and Achievement (commitment following exploration).

rows: Tracks individual change; identifies causal antecedents
Cohort effects; cannot measure individual change
Complex; expensive; still subject to some attrition
questions.correct_value: Separates age, cohort, and time effects
options: Efficient; no attrition; quick results
Tracks individual change; identifies causal antecedents
Separates age, cohort, and time effects
Controls for practice effects; eliminates cohort confounds
questions.explanation: The primary strength of sequential designs is their ability to disentangle age effects, cohort effects, and time-of-measurement effects by combining elements of both longitudinal and cross-sectional approaches. This is what distinguishes them from purely longitudinal designs (which track individual change but are cohort-specific) and cross-sectional designs (which are efficient but confound age and cohort effects).

rows: Preference for human speech over other sounds; can distinguish phonemes from all languages
Babbling: Consonant-vowel combinations ("bababa," "mamama"); initially universal, then narrows to native language sounds
First words: Typically simple nouns referring to familiar objects or people ("mama," "dada," "ball")
Holophrastic speech: Single words used to convey complete ideas ("milk" = "I want milk"); vocabulary grows slowly (~50 words by 18 months)
Vocabulary spurt (naming explosion): Rapid word learning; telegraphic speech: Two-word combinations ("mommy go," "more juice") that omit function words
Rapid grammatical development; sentences of 3+ words; overregularization errors ("goed," "foots") demonstrate rule learning, not imitation
Complex sentences; improving pragmatics; vocabulary of 8,000-14,000 words by age 6
Metalinguistic awareness; understanding of humor, ambiguity, and figurative language
questions.correct_value: Perceptual narrowing: Loss of ability to discriminate non-native phonemes (Werker & Tees, 1984)
options: First words: Typically simple nouns referring to familiar objects or people ("mama," "dada," "ball")
Perceptual narrowing: Loss of ability to discriminate non-native phonemes (Werker & Tees, 1984)
Babbling: Consonant-vowel combinations ("bababa," "mamama"); initially universal, then narrows to native language sounds
Holophrastic speech: Single words used to convey complete ideas ("milk" = "I want milk"); vocabulary grows slowly (~50 words by 18 months)
questions.explanation: At 8-10 months, infants undergo perceptual narrowing, losing the ability to discriminate phonemes not found in their native language. This classic finding by Werker and Tees (1984) is highly testable on the EPPP because it marks a critical shift from universal phoneme perception (present at birth) to language-specific perception, and is easily confused with the earlier babbling stage (4-6 months) when sounds also begin narrowing to the native language.

rows: Low birth weight, preterm birth, SIDS risk, possible behavioral and attentional problems
Prematurity, low birth weight, irritability; earlier claims of severe "crack baby" effects were overstated (Lester et al., 2004)
Possible effects on attention and executive function; research is ongoing and complicated by polydrug use
Generally considered low risk; some studies suggest slightly elevated risk of persistent pulmonary hypertension; benefits often outweigh risks for maternal depression
questions.correct_value: Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS): tremors, irritability, sleep disturbance, feeding difficulties; requires medical management after birth
options: Possible effects on attention and executive function; research is ongoing and complicated by polydrug use
Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS): tremors, irritability, sleep disturbance, feeding difficulties; requires medical management after birth
Prematurity, low birth weight, irritability; earlier claims of severe "crack baby" effects were overstated (Lester et al., 2004)
Low birth weight, preterm birth, SIDS risk, possible behavioral and attentional problems
questions.explanation: Prenatal exposure to opioids (heroin, methadone) is specifically associated with Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS), a withdrawal syndrome characterized by tremors, irritability, sleep disturbance, and feeding difficulties that requires medical management after birth. This is a highly testable association because NAS is a distinct clinical syndrome uniquely linked to opioid exposure, distinguishing it from the effects of other teratogens such as cocaine or tobacco.

rows: Parents provide both genes and environment; the child passively receives both
Musically gifted parents pass on musical genes AND provide instruments and lessons
The child's genetically influenced traits elicit particular responses from the environment
A temperamentally easy baby elicits more positive parenting than a difficult baby
The child actively selects and creates environments compatible with genetic predispositions (also called "niche-picking")
An intellectually curious child seeks out libraries, stimulating peers, and academic challenges
questions.correct_value: Increases with age as autonomy grows
options: Stable across development
Strongest in early childhood
Decreases with age as socialization increases
Increases with age as autonomy grows
questions.explanation: Active rGE (also called 'niche-picking') increases with age because as children grow older, they gain more autonomy to actively select and create environments that match their genetic predispositions. This contrasts with passive rGE, which is strongest in early childhood when parents control the environment, and evocative rGE, which remains relatively stable across development.

questions.section: Level 3: Postconventional (Principled) Morality (A minority of adults; rare before age 20)
rows: "The law is important, but the right to life supersedes the pharmacist's right to profit. The law should be changed to prevent such situations."
Moral reasoning is guided by self-chosen, abstract ethical principles (justice, equality, human dignity) that apply universally. One acts according to these principles even at personal cost.
"He should steal the drug because human life has inherent value that transcends any law. Failing to act would violate the principle of justice."
questions.correct_value: Laws are social contracts that should serve the greatest good. When laws conflict with individual rights, the rights take precedence. Laws can and should be changed through democratic means.
options: Moral reasoning is guided by self-chosen, abstract ethical principles (justice, equality, human dignity) that apply universally. One acts according to these principles even at personal cost.
Laws are social contracts that should serve the greatest good. When laws conflict with individual rights, the rights take precedence. Laws can and should be changed through democratic means.
Right behavior is defined by what is approved by close others or society. Good behavior means fulfilling role expectations and maintaining social order.
Rules are obeyed to avoid punishment or to serve one's own interests. Morality is based on consequences and reciprocal exchange.
questions.explanation: Stage 5 (Social Contract and Individual Rights) emphasizes that laws are social contracts serving the greatest good, but individual rights take precedence when conflicts arise, and laws should be changed democratically. This is commonly confused with Stage 6 (Universal Ethical Principles), which goes further by appealing to self-chosen abstract principles like justice and human dignity that transcend laws entirely, rather than focusing on democratic reform of laws.

rows: Seeks contact, quickly soothed, returns to play
Ignores or avoids caregiver; minimal distress
Clings and resists; difficult to soothe; angry
Frightening or frightened; often linked to maltreatment
questions.correct_value: Contradictory behaviors; freezing, fear, confusion
options: Clings and resists; difficult to soothe; angry
Contradictory behaviors; freezing, fear, confusion
Ignores or avoids caregiver; minimal distress
Seeks contact, quickly soothed, returns to play
questions.explanation: Disorganized/Disoriented (Type D) attachment is characterized by contradictory behaviors such as freezing, expressions of fear, and confusion upon reunion with the caregiver. This pattern reflects the child's lack of a coherent attachment strategy, often resulting from a caregiver who is simultaneously the source of both comfort and fear (e.g., in cases of maltreatment).

questions.correct_value: Will
options: Purpose
Hope
Will
Competence
questions.explanation: In Erikson's second psychosocial stage (Autonomy vs. Shame/Doubt, ages 1-3 years), the virtue that emerges from successful resolution is Will — reflecting the toddler's growing sense of self-control and determination. This is commonly confused with Purpose (Stage 3: Initiative vs. Guilt) and Competence (Stage 4: Industry vs. Inferiority), which are the virtues of adjacent stages.

questions.section: Level 1: Preconventional Morality (Most children under 9; some adolescents and adults)
rows: Actions are judged right or wrong based on whether they lead to punishment. Moral behavior = avoiding punishment. Might makes right.
"He shouldn't steal because he'll go to jail." OR "He should steal because he'll be in trouble if his wife dies."
Right action satisfies one's own needs and occasionally others' needs. Reciprocity is understood as "you scratch my back, I'll scratch yours" -- a concrete, self-interested exchange.
"He should steal it because his wife might return the favor someday." OR "He shouldn't steal because he might get caught and the punishment isn't worth it."
questions.correct_value: Individualism and Exchange (Instrumental Purpose)
options: Obedience and Punishment
Individualism and Exchange (Instrumental Purpose)
Interpersonal Conformity (Good Boy/Nice Girl)
Social Contract and Individual Rights
questions.explanation: Stage 2 of Kohlberg's Preconventional Morality is the Individualism and Exchange (Instrumental Purpose) orientation, where right action is defined by what satisfies one's own needs through concrete, self-interested reciprocity ('you scratch my back, I'll scratch yours'). This is distinct from Stage 1's focus on avoiding punishment, Stage 3's focus on interpersonal approval (Conventional level), and Stage 5's focus on social contracts (Postconventional level).

rows: The child is not engaged in any particular play activity; may watch others, wander, or engage in random movements without clear purpose.
The child plays alone with different toys and makes no effort to interact with or get close to other children. The child is focused on their own activity.
The child watches other children play, may ask questions or make comments, but does not actively participate. The child is interested in others' activities but remains an observer.
The child plays alongside—but not with —other children. Children may use similar materials and be in close proximity but do not coordinate their activities or directly interact.

Children engage in similar activities and there is social interaction (sharing materials, talking, following each other), but there is no organized effort toward a common goal. Each child acts on their own interests.

Children organize play around a common goal, assign roles, negotiate rules, and work together. Examples include building a fort together, playing house with assigned roles, or organized games. This is the most socially sophisticated form of play.
questions.correct_value: 2.5–3.5 years
options: 3–4 years
2–2.5 years
2.5–3.5 years
2.5–3 years
questions.explanation: Parallel play, in which children play alongside but not with other children, occurs at approximately 2.5–3.5 years according to Parten's stages. This is easily confused with onlooker play (2.5–3 years) and associative play (3–4 years), which are the stages immediately before and after parallel play in the developmental sequence.

rows: Most common (~60–70% of dementias); gradual onset; progressive decline
Early memory loss (especially recent events); neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques; genetic risk includes APOE-e4 allele
Second most common; results from cerebrovascular damage
Stepwise decline (following strokes); may co-occur with Alzheimer's; associated with cardiovascular risk factors
Third most common; Lewy bodies in cortex
Younger onset (often 45–65); frontal and temporal lobe degeneration
Personality and behavioral changes (disinhibition, apathy) precede memory loss; includes Pick's disease
questions.correct_value: Visual hallucinations; fluctuating cognition; parkinsonism; sensitivity to antipsychotics
options: Stepwise decline (following strokes); may co-occur with Alzheimer's; associated with cardiovascular risk factors
Visual hallucinations; fluctuating cognition; parkinsonism; sensitivity to antipsychotics
Early memory loss (especially recent events); neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques; genetic risk includes APOE-e4 allele
Personality and behavioral changes (disinhibition, apathy) precede memory loss; includes Pick's disease
questions.explanation: Lewy Body Dementia is distinctively characterized by visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, parkinsonian motor features, and a notable sensitivity to antipsychotic medications. The sensitivity to antipsychotics is a particularly high-yield distinguishing feature for the EPPP, as it has critical clinical implications for treatment decisions and differentiates it from other dementias.

rows: Explains vocabulary learning and pragmatic aspects
questions.correct_value: Explains universality, speed, creativity, and rule-governed nature
options: Integrates biological and environmental contributions
Explains universality, speed, creativity, and rule-governed nature
Explains vocabulary learning and pragmatic aspects
Explains innate grammatical structures through social reinforcement
questions.explanation: Chomsky's Nativist theory is best known for explaining why language acquisition is universal across cultures, occurs rapidly during a critical period, allows for creative sentence generation, and follows systematic grammatical rules — all of which support the existence of an innate Language Acquisition Device (LAD). This distinguishes it from the Behaviorist emphasis on vocabulary/pragmatics and the Interactionist focus on combining biology with social input.

rows: Object permanence, goal-directed behavior, mental representation
Conservation, classification, seriation, logical operations on concrete objects
Abstract reasoning, hypothetical-deductive thinking, propositional thought
questions.correct_value: Symbolic thought, egocentrism, centration, irreversibility
options: Conservation, classification, seriation, logical operations on concrete objects
Symbolic thought, egocentrism, centration, irreversibility
Abstract reasoning, hypothetical-deductive thinking, propositional thought
Object permanence, goal-directed behavior, mental representation
questions.explanation: The Preoperational stage (ages 2–7) is characterized by symbolic thought, egocentrism, centration, and irreversibility. Children in this stage can use symbols and language but cannot yet perform logical operations, leading to errors such as focusing on one dimension of a problem (centration) and failing to mentally reverse transformations (irreversibility). These features are commonly confused with the Concrete Operational stage, which is when children overcome these limitations and acquire conservation and classification abilities.

rows: Turns head toward stimulus, opens mouth
Sudden drop of head or loud noise
Held upright with feet on surface
questions.correct_value: 8-12 months
options: 3-4 months
5-6 months
8-12 months
2-3 months
questions.explanation: The Babinski reflex (toes fan out and up when the sole of the foot is stroked) disappears at 8-12 months, making it the longest-lasting neonatal reflex listed. This is commonly tested because it persists significantly longer than other reflexes and its persistence beyond 12 months can indicate neurological abnormalities.

rows: Amount of physical movement during daily activities
Predictability of biological functions (sleep, feeding, elimination)
Initial response to new stimuli (people, places, foods)
Ease of adjusting to changes in routine or environment
Energy level of responses (positive or negative)
Degree to which extraneous stimuli alter ongoing behavior
Length of time devoted to an activity and continuation despite obstacles
questions.correct_value: Intensity of stimulation needed to elicit a response
options: Energy level of responses (positive or negative)
Intensity of stimulation needed to elicit a response
Degree to which extraneous stimuli alter ongoing behavior
Ease of adjusting to changes in routine or environment
questions.explanation: Threshold of responsiveness refers to the intensity of stimulation needed to elicit a response. This is commonly confused with 'intensity of reaction,' which instead refers to the energy level of a response once it occurs. Threshold is about the input (how much stimulation is needed), while intensity is about the output (how strong the response is).

rows: Sits with support; then sits independently
Runs; kicks a ball; climbs stairs with both feet on each step
Hops on one foot; pedals a tricycle; catches a bounced ball
Skips; rides a bicycle with training wheels; ties shoelaces
questions.correct_value: Pulls to stand; cruises along furniture
options: Crawls (some children skip crawling entirely)
Walks independently (average; range: 9-17 months)
Pulls to stand; cruises along furniture
Sits with support; then sits independently
questions.explanation: At 9-10 months, infants typically pull themselves to a standing position and begin cruising (walking while holding onto furniture). This is a key transitional milestone between crawling (7-8 months) and independent walking (around 12 months), and is frequently tested because candidates may confuse the specific age ranges for these closely sequenced motor milestones.

rows: Forming close, committed relationships; capacity for intimacy requires a firm sense of identity
Contributing to the next generation through parenting, mentoring, creative work, or community involvement
Reflecting on one's life with acceptance; viewing it as meaningful and well-lived vs. filled with regret
questions.correct_value: Care
options: Wisdom
Love
Will
Care
questions.explanation: In Erikson's Stage 7 (Middle Adulthood), the crisis of Generativity vs. Stagnation yields the virtue of Care. This reflects the adult's concern for establishing and guiding the next generation. 'Love' is the virtue of Stage 6 (Intimacy vs. Isolation), and 'Wisdom' is the virtue of Stage 8 (Ego Integrity vs. Despair). 'Will' is the virtue from the earlier stage of Autonomy vs. Shame and Doubt.

rows: Production of vowel-like sounds ("ooo," "aah"); social in nature
Consonant-vowel combinations ("bababa," "mamama"); increasingly resembles native language
Imitation of speech sounds; varied syllable combinations
Typically referential (naming objects/people); vocabulary of ~1–3 words
Single words used to convey entire sentences ("milk" = "I want milk")
Rapid word acquisition (~50+ words); two-word combinations ("mommy go," "more juice")
questions.correct_value: Holophrastic stage
options: Telegraphic speech
Holophrastic stage
Echolalia / variegated babbling
Vocabulary spurt
questions.explanation: The holophrastic stage (12–18 months) is characterized by a child using single words to convey the meaning of entire sentences (e.g., saying 'milk' to mean 'I want milk'). This is distinct from telegraphic speech (18–24 months), which involves two-word combinations, and from echolalia/variegated babbling (8–10 months), which involves imitation of speech sounds rather than meaningful word use.

rows: Self-interest; "what's in it for me?"; reciprocal exchange
"Good boy/good girl" orientation; meeting others' expectations; maintaining relationships
Maintaining social order; following rules and laws; duty to society
Abstract principles of justice, dignity, equality; conscience-directed
questions.correct_value: Rights, democratic principles; laws serve the greater good but can be changed
options: Maintaining social order; following rules and laws; duty to society
Abstract principles of justice, dignity, equality; conscience-directed
Rights, democratic principles; laws serve the greater good but can be changed
"Good boy/good girl" orientation; meeting others' expectations; maintaining relationships
questions.explanation: Stage 5 (Social Contract) is characterized by the understanding that laws and rules are social agreements that serve the greater good but can be legitimately changed through democratic processes. This distinguishes it from Stage 6, which relies on abstract universal ethical principles directed by individual conscience, and from Stage 4, which emphasizes rigid adherence to existing laws and social order.

rows: Explains vocabulary learning and pragmatic aspects
questions.correct_value: Explains universality, speed, and creativity of acquisition
options: Explains vocabulary learning and pragmatic aspects
Explains universality, speed, and creativity of acquisition
Integrates biological and social contributions
Explains rule-governed behavior through operant conditioning
questions.explanation: The Nativist theory, proposed by Chomsky, posits an innate Language Acquisition Device (LAD) and Universal Grammar. Its primary strength is that it accounts for the universality of language across cultures, the remarkable speed at which children acquire language, and children's ability to produce and understand novel sentences (creativity) — phenomena that are difficult to explain through reinforcement or imitation alone.

questions.section: Level 2: Conventional Morality (Most adolescents and adults)
rows: Being moral means living up to the expectations of people close to you. Emphasis on being "good," gaining approval, and maintaining relationships. Intentions begin to matter.
"He should steal it because that's what a good husband would do." OR "He shouldn't steal because people will think he's a criminal."
Moral behavior means obeying laws, respecting authority, and fulfilling one's duties to maintain social order. Laws exist for the good of society.
"He shouldn't steal because if everyone stole, society would break down." OR "He should steal because he has a duty to protect his wife, but he should accept the legal consequences."
questions.correct_value: Good Interpersonal Relationships ("Good Boy/Nice Girl")
options: Maintaining Social Order (Law and Order)
Good Interpersonal Relationships ("Good Boy/Nice Girl")
Individualism and Exchange
Social Contract and Individual Rights
questions.explanation: Stage 3 of Kohlberg's moral development is the 'Good Interpersonal Relationships' or 'Good Boy/Nice Girl' orientation, where morality is defined by living up to the expectations of those close to you, gaining approval, and maintaining relationships. This is distinct from Stage 4's 'Maintaining Social Order' orientation, which focuses on obeying laws and fulfilling duties to preserve social order.

rows: Self-interest; "what's in it for me?"; reciprocal exchange

questions.correct_value: "Good boy/good girl" orientation; meeting others' expectations; maintaining relationships
options: Maintaining social order; following rules and laws; duty to society
"Good boy/good girl" orientation; meeting others' expectations; maintaining relationships
Self-interest; "what's in it for me?"; reciprocal exchange
Rights, democratic principles; laws serve the greater good but can be changed
questions.explanation: Stage 3 (Interpersonal Conformity) in Kohlberg's theory is characterized by the 'good boy/good girl' orientation, where moral judgments are based on meeting others' expectations and maintaining interpersonal relationships. This is commonly confused with Stage 4 (Law & Order), which shifts the focus from interpersonal approval to maintaining broader social order and following established laws.

rows: Explains universality, speed, and creativity of acquisition
Explains vocabulary learning and pragmatic aspects
questions.correct_value: Bruner, Tomasello
options: Vygotsky, Piaget
Chomsky, Pinker
Bruner, Tomasello
Skinner, Bandura
questions.explanation: The interactionist approach to language development, which emphasizes the interplay between biological endowment and social interaction, is most closely associated with Jerome Bruner (who proposed the Language Acquisition Support System, or LASS) and Michael Tomasello (who emphasized joint attention and shared intentionality). These theorists are distinct from nativists like Chomsky or behaviorists like Skinner.
